nodes.text: In an overlapping-generations neoclassical growth model, the issuance and composition of government debt (external vs internal) systematically affect long-run competitive equilibrium outcomes such as interest rates, capital stock, and the long-run utility of individuals

Model framework: discrete-time overlapping-generations economy with infinitely many periods, individuals live two periods, production with a constant-returns-to-scale aggregate function F(K,L), no depreciation, consumption and capital are same commodity, wages equal marginal product of labor, interest equals marginal product of capital

Centrally planned benchmarks: Golden Age Paths (constant capital-labor ratio) and Golden Rule path where marginal product of capital equals population growth rate; planners maximize lifetime utility subject to resource constraint

Competitive equilibrium characterization: individuals choose consumption/saving given wage and market interest rate yielding aggregate supply St = L t s(wt, rt+1); equilibrium interest satisfies rt+1 = f'(St/Lt+1) and may be dynamically inefficient (competitive r can differ from growth rate n)

Government debt specification and assumptions: analyze external vs internal one-period debt with constant debt-labor ratios (debt grows at population rate n), interest paid at current market rate, lump-sum taxes on the young finance residual interest, long-run (steady-state) comparative statics emphasized

External debt effect (result): in the normal efficient case (r > n) externally held debt reduces long-run individual utility because taxes to finance foreign interest and the induced rise in equilibrium interest move the economy away from the Golden Rule

Internal debt effect (result): internally held government debt reduces private capital via two channels (tax-financed interest and substitution of government debt for physical capital), and in the normal efficient case internal debt lowers long-run individual utility, often more than external debt

Mechanism 1 (tax effect): taxes used to finance interest payments directly reduce disposable lifetime consumption and, by lowering disposable income, reduce private saving and hence the steady-state capital stock

Mechanism 2 (portfolio substitution): internal debt substitutes government paper for physical capital in private portfolios, directly reducing the capital-labor ratio and output even when taxes are unchanged

Equilibrium shifts and stability: debt alters the saving schedule and hence shifts the implicit function r = q(w); implicit differentiation and stability conditions show debt changes equilibrium r and w and whether r moves toward or away from n depends on capital market slopes and parameter values

Debt swap (result): replacing external debt with internal debt (issuing internal to retire external) raises the equilibrium interest rate by increasing domestic government demand for funds, reduces the capital-labor ratio, and in the efficient case unambiguously lowers long-run individual utility

Ambiguity in the inefficient case: if the competitive solution is dynamically inefficient (r < n), the signs of welfare effects reverse or become ambiguous—additional debt or a debt swap can raise private utility because moving r toward n can increase welfare

Conclusion: in the standard efficient competitive case (r > n) both external and internal debt reduce long-run utility (internal typically worse), and swapping external for internal debt lowers welfare; in the inefficient case (r < n) these conclusions can reverse or be ambiguous

Model limitations and assumptions: two-period lives, no depreciation, no bequests, lump-sum taxation on the young, one-period maturity debt, perfect certainty—these restrict applicability and can affect intergenerational incidence and bequest responses

Assumption on debt scaling: to have permanent long-run effects the model holds the debt-labor ratio constant (debt grows at rate n) so a fixed absolute debt would vanish asymptotically in a growing economy

Additional result: external debt shifts the saving schedule so that the equilibrium interest rate moves further from the Golden Rule (in the normal case), increasing the gap |r - n| and thereby contributing to the welfare loss from external debt
